with Scouting Reports by Danny Kelly

Welcome to The Ringer’s 2019 NFL Draft Guide. Consider this your hub for all things draft-related leading up to the first round on April 25. It’ll include prospect rankings, scouting reports, mock drafts, and much more—and best of all, we will be updating it regularly with new analysis that takes all of the latest developments into account.

At launch, the guide featured Danny Kelly’s Big Board, highlighting the 32 players he was highest on coming out of college football season. That list soon expanded, and we unveiled the first of many mock drafts. On the heels of the combine, we rolled out thorough scouting evaluations of every prized prospect. And in April we added breakdowns of team needs from Robert Mays to make sense of the league landscape after a flurry of free-agent moves. Click through all the tabs to get the full breadth of our analysis.

Who will the Cardinals take at no. 1? Whose stock will rise and fall? Which future All-Pros are flying under the radar? Check back often to see where things stand. Draft season is officially on the clock.

1

Daniel Jones

Quarterback

Duke, redshirt junior

  • YDS 2674
  • YPA 6.8
  • TDS 22
  • INTS 9
  • RTG 131.7
Height/Weight6'5'', 221
Age21
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Tools

Big, athletic quarterback with good accuracy in the short and intermediate areas but spotty downfield touch.

Shades Of: Blake Bortles
Scouting Report

Jones has the physical makeup to develop into a pro passer, with prototypical size, top-tier athleticism, and a good arm. He is a three-year starter who learned under former Eli and Peyton Manning tutor David Cutcliffe at Duke, and playing in an RPO-heavy offense, he displayed the ability to go through reads and throw with accuracy at the short and intermediate levels. Jones is very athletic, capable of running away from defenders if he finds some daylight, and rushed for 17 touchdowns in his college career. He struggled to throw with anticipation at times, though, and was scattershot with his deep accuracy, finishing with a 69.0 passer rating on deep passes in 2018, per Pro Football Focus, which ranked seventh worst of 50 qualifying quarterbacks in this class. Jones’s receivers dropped an incredible amount of passes, but his college statistics do not paint the picture of a future NFL starter: He finished his career averaging just 6.4 yards per attempt with a 60 percent completion rate and 29 interceptions to go along with his 52 touchdowns. He displayed questionable decision-making, launching throws from off-balance platforms or forcing passes into coverage, and struggled under pressure.

Why He Could Rise

Jones has the type of moldable traits that NFL teams are looking for; with good size, arm strength, and short and intermediate accuracy, he has the potential to eventually develop into a starter-caliber NFL passer.

Why He Could Fall

He displays questionable decision-making, throws far too many interceptions, and was very inaccurate on deep passes.

Combine Results

  • Hand size 9 3/4''
  • Arm length 32 1/2''
  • 40-yard dash time 4.81
  • 3-cone drill time 7
  • Short shuttle time 4.41

2

Chase Winovich

Edge Rusher

Michigan, redshirt senior

  • TKLS 69
  • TFL 17
  • Sacks 5
Height/Weight6'3'', 256
Age24
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Tenacity and burst

Aggressive, ferocious edge rusher who plays with explosion and a high motor.

Shades Of: Clay Matthews
Scouting Report

Winovich has a rock-solid frame and a quick first step. He springs out of his stance to attack upfield, using active hands and his revved-up motor to threaten the edge and pursue the quarterback to the whistle. He has good bend to dip and rip around the corner. He plays with a feisty, aggressive persona but can get out of control at times; he occasionally leans too far forward in his rush, allowing savvy tackles to throw him to the ground. Winovich is a very good run defender and a reliable, forceful tackler—but he can lose sight of the ballcarrier as he’s trying to make his way upfield. He’s a good athlete with plenty of agility, as illustrated by the elite 1.55 10-yard split he posted in his combine 40-yard dash and his 6.94-second three-cone time.

Why He Could Rise

Winovich is a disruptive, rugged edge defender with a three-down skill set and a motor that always runs hot.

Why He Could Fall

He’s aggressive to the point of recklessness, too often playing out over his skis as he shoots forward at the snap; he lacks the prototypical length.

  • Arm length 32 3/4''
  • 3-cone drill time 6.94
  • Short shuttle time 4.11
  • Broad jump 116''
  • Vertical jump 30.5''

3

Tytus Howard

Tackle

Alabama State, redshirt senior

  • GMS 10
  • STRTS 10
  • Sk ALL 1
Height/Weight6'5'', 322
Age22
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Moldable traits

Developmental tackle with prototypical size, good feet, and smooth athleticism.

Shades Of: Bobby Massie
Scouting Report

Howard is a former high school quarterback and walk-on to Alabama State who started out at tight end before transitioning to offensive line. He has a massive frame with a powerful base, long arms, and meat hooks for hands, and boasts basketball athleticism. He logged starts for the Hornets at both right and left tackle, using good bend and light feet to mirror pass rushers on the edge. He’s still raw at the position and is inconsistent when it comes to landing his punch, but when he can get his hands on an opponent, he plays with leverage and torque to control the rush. He’s got the size, power, and footwork to generate movement in the run game. Howard is still growing into the position, but has all the traits that offensive line coaches are looking for.

Why He Could Rise

Howard has the size, length, and feet to develop into a quality tackle.

Why He Could Fall

He not only has to continue to learn the nuances of the position, but must now deal with NFL speed after playing at a lower level of competition at Alabama State.

4

Max Scharping

Tackle

Northern Illinois, redshirt senior

  • GMS 14
  • STRTS 14
  • Sk ALL 1
Height/Weight6'6'', 327
Age22
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Dependability and pass protection

Athletic, durable offensive tackle with good feet, versatility, and length.

Shades Of: Braden Smith
Scouting Report

Scharping is an athletic tackle with good height and a well-proportioned frame, wearing his 327 pounds like a man 30 pounds lighter. He has experience at right tackle and right guard, and started at left tackle the past two seasons. Scharping glides in pass protection and covers ground while working as a blocker in space. He keeps his punch inside and has strong hands. He leans back at times at the start of his set and will mistime his punch, but when he latches on to his opponent, he can generate torque in his upper body to control his opponent. In the run game, Scharping gives good effort and does well to effectively wall off defenders, but is not a road grader at the point of attack.

Why He Could Rise

Scharping is a steadfast and reliable pass protector who brings plenty of grit in the ground game and the ability to play multiple positions on the line.

Why He Could Fall

He played at a lower level of competition, needs refinement in his technique, and could improve as a run blocker.

5

Anthony Nelson

Edge Rusher

Iowa, redshirt junior

  • TKLS 45
  • TFL 13.5
  • Sacks 9.5
Height/Weight6'7'', 271
Age21
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Length and upside

Long, highly athletic, and productive strongside end with potential as an inside rusher.

Shades Of: Margus Hunt lite
Scouting Report

Nelson is an athletic strongside end with rare length and loads of untapped upside. The former Hawkeyes defender isn’t super twitched up but has very good functional strength and lateral agility. He uses a deadly long-arm stab move early in his rush to get offensive linemen on their heels, and flashes an effective push-pull-rip move as a counter. He can bend at the last second to finish his rush, and posted strong numbers in 2018, racking up 9.5 sacks. Per Pro Football Focus, he notched 53 pressures on the year—tied for tops among Big Ten edge rushers—and his 23.5 percent pass-rush win rate was also first in the conference. Against the run, Nelson stacks blockers while keeping eyes in the backfield, then shakes his opponent to tackle the ballcarrier.

Why He Could Rise

Nelson has rare length to go with versatility, consistency, athleticism, and production.

Why He Could Fall

He lacks top-tier speed, explosion, and bend; will need to prove he can shoot gaps as an interior pass rusher.

  • Arm length 34 7/8''
  • 3-cone drill time 6.95
  • Short shuttle time 4.23
  • Broad jump 118''
  • Vertical jump 35.5''

Miles Boykin

Wide Receiver

Notre Dame, senior

  • YDS 872
  • YPR 14.78
  • TDS 8
  • REC 59
  • 20+ 17
Height/Weight6'4'', 220
Age21
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: X-receiver skill set

Smooth athlete with the speed to take the top off a defense and the jump-ball skills to win at the catch point.

Shades Of: Terrelle Pryor
Scouting Report

Boykin is a supreme athlete with the combination of size, physicality, and athleticism to develop into a prototypical X receiver. The former Notre Dame standout is sudden off the line and has no trouble beating press coverage to get downfield. He has long-striding speed downfield, shows awareness of the sideline on catches, and is adept at using his size and positioning to draw pass interference penalties. He’s a strong route runner who doesn’t betray his intentions before making his cut and has very good hands, regularly plucking the ball away from his frame. He can contort in the air to bring down an off-target pass. In the run game, he’s an aggressive blocker who sticks with his assignment all the way through the whistle.

Why He Could Rise

Boykin is an elite athlete with big frame who’s just scratching the surface of his potential.

Why He Could Fall

He didn’t post gaudy numbers and needs to be more consistently aggressive at the catch point.

7

Emanuel Hall

Wide Receiver

Missouri, senior

  • YDS 828
  • YPR 22.38
  • TDS 6
  • REC 37
  • 20+ 16
Height/Weight6'2'', 201
Age21
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Field-stretching speed

Springy, electric pass catcher with explosiveness off the line and elite downfield speed.

Shades Of: Robby Anderson, Martavis Bryant
Scouting Report

Hall boasts elite downfield speed; the former Tiger is an electric deep threat who averaged 23.6 yards per catch over the past two seasons. He has excellent foot quickness and uses jukes, head fakes, and his hands to discard press coverage and push downfield. Against off-coverage, he eats up a cornerback’s cushion in a hurry and often runs right past his defender. Hall is agile after the catch, able to make defenders miss and pick up extra yards. He could stand to be more aggressive at the catch point, too often waiting for the ball instead of attacking it. He’s not much help as a blocker and may need to take his play demeanor up a notch or three in the NFL. He’s best paired with a signal-caller who’s not afraid to unleash passes deep and who throws with anticipation.

Why He Could Rise

Hall has the take-the-top-off-a-defense speed that teams will have to account for on every snap.

Why He Could Fall

He struggled with drops at times and is still raw as a route runner.

Combine Results

  • Hand size 9 3/4''
  • 40-yard dash time 4.39
  • Vertical jump 43.5

Will Grier

Quarterback

West Virginia, redshirt senior

  • YDS 3864
  • YPA 9.7
  • TDS 37
  • INTS 8
  • RTG 175.5
Height/Weight6'2'', 217
Age24
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Sexy deep ball

Aggressive passer with pinpoint accuracy and downy-soft touch on vertical downfield throws.

Shades Of: Ryan Fitzpatrick
Scouting Report

Grier is a smooth, confident passer who loves to attack defenses deep. He has a good arm (his ball velocity clocked in at 59 mph at the combine, tied for best in the class) and exhibits top-tier accuracy and touch in the vertical passing game. He racked up the most pass attempts and completions of 20-plus yards in college football the last two seasons combined, per Pro Football Focus. The former Mountaineers signal-caller is very accurate in the intermediate passing attack, too, and is most dangerous when he drops back and throws on time. But when he’s forced to move off his spot or improvise, his footwork, accuracy, decision-making, and pass velocity all erode; he often tries to do too much, throws off-balance, or forces it into coverage in those situations. Grier plays mostly out of shotgun looks in West Virginia's Air Raid–style offense.

Why He Could Rise

Grier is an aggressive and accurate deep-ball passer with the upside to develop into a starter in a vertical-oriented offense.

Why He Could Fall

He struggles under pressure or when moved off his spot. Is slightly undersized, and some teams may see backup potential only.

  • Arm length 31 1/2''

David Long

Cornerback

Michigan, junior

  • TKLS 17
  • INTS 1
  • PBU 8
Height/Weight5'11'', 196
Age21
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Sticky coverage skills

Ornery press corner with lightning feet who’s tough to shake downfield.

Shades Of: Desmond King
Scouting Report

Long is a fiery and physical press cornerback. He jabs and spars with receivers at the snap before transitioning smoothly, strafing laterally or flipping his hips to match steps with his opponent. He shows easy confidence in coverage, maintains subtle contact with the receiver throughout the route, and was rarely targeted in 2018. Long displays the ability to mirror and trail receivers from the slot, and while he may lack elite long-speed deep, he’s almost never beaten by quickness. He could have a future in the slot but may need to be more subtle with his hand-fighting at the next level to avoid penalties.

Why He Could Rise

Long sticks to receivers like glue while playing an aggressive and physical brand of coverage.

Why He Could Fall

He lacks length, with just 30.75-inch arms, and has a slight frame; he rarely played off coverage and may need time to adjust to other scheme techniques.

Andy Isabella

Wide Receiver

UMass, senior

  • YDS 1698
  • YPR 16.65
  • TDS 13
  • REC 102
  • 20+ 25
Height/Weight5'9'', 188
Age22
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Electric speed

Undersized but ultraproductive pass catcher with lightning feet and take-a-top-off-the-defense speed.

Shades Of: Tyler Lockett
Scouting Report

Isabella has a compact, muscled frame and boasts track speed. He’s quick off the line, and while some teams may see him as a slot receiver only, he played all over the field for UMass and was a dangerous downfield threat who tied for the national lead with 11 receptions of 40-plus yards. Isabella has impressive acceleration off the line, can change direction on a dime, and is elusive after the catch, creating yards for himself on screens. He shows excellent awareness on catches near the sideline to keep his feet inbounds, and because corners respect his deep speed, he’s good on comeback routes and hitches. He had some trouble with drops, will need to avoid body-catching at the next level, and has a small catch radius.

Why He Could Rise

Isabella pairs elite deep speed and human-joystick-like agility in the short and intermediate zones; he was wildly productive in college.

Why He Could Fall

His small frame could cause durability concerns and some teams may see him as a slot receiver only.

Zach Allen

Edge Rusher

Boston College, senior

  • TKLS 61
  • TFL 15
  • Sacks 6.5
Height/Weight6'4'', 281
Age21
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Strength and length

Big, athletic defensive end who dominates against the run and packs power as a pass rusher.

Shades Of: Henry Anderson
Scouting Report

Allen is an athletic defensive end with massive size and an intimidating on-field demeanor. If you squint, the former Boston College standout looks a little like J.J. Watt; he’s not nearly as explosive as the three-time Defensive Player of the Year but does possess good first-step burst, pack plenty of power in his hands, and know how to use his length as leverage. Allen has to win early in his rush or he can get stalemated, and, while he’s not consistently going to threaten the edge against pro tackles, he showed he can get to the quarterback with a repertoire of block-beating moves, including a strong swim move and powerful club-rip. He’s a dominant run defender and has notched 40.5 tackles for a loss in the past three seasons. His massive wingspan gives him a wide tackle radius and helps him stack linemen and shed blocks. He knocked down seven passes and blocked two kicks in 2018. He projects as a strongside defensive end in a 4-3 or 5-technique in a 3-4.

Why He Could Rise

Allen combines size, athleticism, positional versatility, and power; he should be a high-floor contributor to any line.

Why He Could Fall

He lacks explosiveness as a pass rusher and struggles to bend and change directions.

  • 3-cone drill time 7.34

Darrell Henderson

Running Back

Memphis, junior

  • YDS 1909
  • YPC 8.92
  • TDS 22
  • REC 19
  • 20+ 32
Height/Weight5'8'', 208
Age21
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Big-play talent

Undersized but explosive home run hitter with a distinctive slashing style.

Shades Of: Andre Ellington, Devonta Freeman
Scouting Report

Henderson is a speedy, elusive, and astoundingly productive back who averaged 8.9 yards per carry over the past two seasons while racking up 3,584 scrimmage yards and 36 touchdowns along the way. The AP first-team All-American can deliver some pop, has good contact balance to break through arm tackle attempts, and led the draft class in yards after contact per carry, per Pro Football Focus. He’s a slashing, slalom-style runner who seeks daylight and often finds it. He’s explosive in the open field and quickly gets up to top speed when he sees even a sliver of daylight. The former Tiger led the country in runs of both 20-plus yards (27) and 40-plus yards (12) in 2018. He sets up his blocks at the second level, peeking one way to get a defender to commit before cutting the other direction to break free. Henderson was frequently deployed taking direct snaps in wildcat looks and has upside as a pass-catching threat with 63 receptions and eight touchdowns in his college career. He’s not the most laterally elusive back and won’t make many defenders miss behind the line of scrimmage.

Why He Could Rise

Henderson can create explosive plays from anywhere on the field and should be a factor in the passing attack.

Why He Could Fall

He lacks size, and some teams may see him as best suited for a complementary role.

Combine Results

  • 40-yard dash time 4.49
  • Vertical jump 33.5''
  • Broad jump 121''

How Did We Get
Here with Kyler
Murray?
BY Rodger Sherman

I cannot believe that we’ve gotten to this point with Kyler Murray. I’d already given up on the idea of ever seeing him play football again. His lone season as Oklahoma’s starting quarterback was one of the greatest introductions to the sport that a player has ever made, and it also felt like one of the great farewell tours. It’s rare and beautiful for a first-year starter to win the Heisman Trophy; it’s rarer and more poignant for that guy to be someone who has already committed to a career in another sport. The Oakland A’s nabbed Murray ninth overall in the 2018 MLB draft, guaranteeing him millions of dollars to give up life as an undersized QB to become one of the centerpieces of the franchise’s outfield plan. Murray’s future was set.

Until he made clear that he is better at playing quarterback than he ever will be at anything else, that is. Murray just put together the second-most efficient passing season in college football history, and was even more impressive as a runner. I’ve never seen anybody else change directions at high speeds the way he does. I cannot stress this enough: In baseball, players almost never change directions. They are required, by rule, to run counterclockwise around a diamond. Football is the sport for Kyler.

For the life of me, I’ll never understand why the A’s drafted Murray and then let him play football for the Sooners. They ran the risk of injury, for one, and also the risk of this—Murray emerging as a superstar in the other sport and never coming back to baseball. The A’s let Murray realize his football destiny. Even if he doesn’t pan out in the NFL, I’ll be forever grateful for their mistake.

Miami Dolphins
Miami Dolphins

Blake Cashman

Linebacker

Minnesota, senior

  • TKLS 104
  • TFL 15
  • Sacks 2.5
Height/Weight6'1'', 237
Age22
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Instincts and athleticism

Rangy, tenacious off-ball linebacker with excellent quickness and top-tier tackling prowess.

Shades Of: Matt Milano
Scouting Report

Cashman is a compact, athletic linebacker prospect with good play speed, range in coverage, and excellent production. The former Gopher attacks the run with fury, sifting through the trash to get himself into position and taking on blocks with ferocious attitude. He’s quick to react and can slip off blocks to make tackles. He is strong coming downhill and racked up 15.0 tackles for a loss and 2.5 sacks in 2018. He struggled at times with identifying misdirection. While he lacks length, he makes up for it in fundamental tackling technique. In coverage, he shows awareness in zones and the instincts to read route combinations but may be overmatched against bigger, longer tight ends in man coverage down the seam. He has the athleticism to carry running backs out of the backfield.

Why He Could Rise

Cashman has outstanding sideline-to-sideline speed and is an extremely reliable tackler.

Why He Could Fall

He’s slightly undersized and may be limited to playing on the weak side in the NFL.

  • Short shuttle time 4.12

Renell Wren

Interior Defensive Lineman

Arizona State, redshirt senior

  • TKLS 43
  • TFL 4.5
  • Sacks 1
Height/Weight6'5'', 318
Age23
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Underutilized explosiveness

Long, well-built defensive tackle with an intriguing blend of athleticism and power.

Shades Of: DaQuan Jones, Akiem Hicks
Scouting Report

Wren is a massive, muscled-up defensive lineman with an explosive first step and a shocking punch. He fires out of his stance at the snap to knock offensive linemen back into the pocket, but his sack production was disappointing as he lined up primarily at the nose tackle spot. Technique-wise, he is more of a bull in a china shop than a disciplined, fundamental rusher at this point in his career. When his initial surge is stopped, he often pops upright, loses his leverage, and gets washed out of the play or knocked off his feet. His draft stock is connected to where teams project him at the next level: Because of his top-tier athleticism, he has a high floor as a penetrating, gap-shooting three-technique defensive tackle, where his quick-twitch burst and power can be better utilized.

Why He Could Rise

Wren has elite athletic traits, massive size, and plenty of length.

Why He Could Fall

He lacked in production, grabbing just 3.0 career sacks, and needs work on his pass-rushing technique.

  • Arm length 33 7/8''
  • 3-cone drill time 7.65
  • Short shuttle time 4.53
  • Broad jump 118''
  • Vertical jump 32''

Germaine Pratt

Linebacker

NC State, redshirt senior

Scouting Report

Pratt is an athletic, versatile linebacker who is a consistent and reliable tackler and an excellent blitzer. He showed a nose for the ball for the Wolfpack, racking up 104 tackles—including 10 for a loss—plus three passes defensed and two forced fumbles in 2018. The former safety understands how routes develop in coverage and showed off excellent effective range and a smooth transition to trailing position to carry running backs or tight ends downfield. He has very good closing burst and tackle radius and the potential to play inside or outside in both 3-4 and 4-3 schemes. He takes on blocks with a far-too-upright technique, though, leaving him susceptible to getting knocked back or sealed out of the play too easily. He’s still raw at the position, and there may be a learning curve in the transition to the pros.

Why He Could Rise

Pratt is strong against the run and smooth in coverage, and he offers tantalizing upside as a dynamic blitzer and situational pass rusher.

Why He Could Fall

His block-shedding technique needs work, and he’s still learning the intricacies of the position.

Should NFL Teams
Tank for
Tua &
Trevor?
BY Rodger Sherman

The two most pro-ready quarterbacks from college football last season are not in the 2019 NFL draft.

Alabama’s Tua Tagovailoa is the best QB prospect I’ve ever seen. There is never a point during any play when he believes he cannot throw a touchdown—and over time, I’ve come to learn that with his outrageous arm, rare vision, and excellent mobility, he’s capable of just that. Despite being a risk-taker, he didn’t throw an interception until he already had 26 touchdown passes in the 2018 campaign. And he had the poise to win a national championship as a true freshman. There’s just one problem for NFL teams: He isn’t eligible to join the league until after his junior season, so they’ll have to wait to draft him until 2020 at the earliest.

To some scouts, Clemson’s Trevor Lawrence (who beat Tagovailoa’s Alabama team in January’s national title game) is the best quarterback prospect they’ve ever seen. He has prototypical size, a stronger arm than Tagovailoa, and oh yeah—the poise to win a national championship as a true freshman. There’s just one problem for NFL teams: He isn’t eligible to join the league until after his junior season, so they’ll have to wait to draft him until 2021 at the earliest.

Quarterbacks are more polished at younger ages than they’ve ever been, and Tagovailoa and Lawrence are the leaders of this trend. They appeared ready for the NFL from the moment they stepped on campus, and as more QBs like them come along, we’ll likely see a wave of pushback against the age restriction that prevents prospects from becoming draft-eligible until they’re three years removed from high school. If both players were eligible now, Tagovailoa and Lawrence would almost certainly be the no. 1 and no. 2 picks in this year’s draft. (Probably Lawrence first, then Tagovailoa.)

Allowing teams to draft freshmen would change the shape of the draft. With less time to evaluate players, there would be even wilder swings and misses than we’re used to. But Lawrence and Tagovailoa would be worth it. That’s great news for fans of teams that were actually good in 2018: The most important tanking opportunities of the decade lie ahead.

Philadelphia Eagles
Philadelphia Eagles

Scouting Report

Hurd is a former five-star running back who started his college career in Tennessee’s backfield before transferring to Baylor and switching to receiver. Why He Could Fall

He’s raw, posted a disappointing 4.66-second 40-yard dash at his pro day, and is an older prospect after sitting out a year following his transfer from Tennessee.

KeeSean Johnson

Wide Receiver

Fresno State, redshirt senior

  • YDS 1340
  • YPR 14.11
  • TDS 8
  • REC 95
  • 20+ 26
Height/Weight6'1'', 201
Age22
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Size and reliable hands

Smooth, intuitive route runner with big mitts and the ability to pick up yards after the catch.

Shades Of: Tyler Boyd
Scouting Report

Johnson is a natural playmaker who posted 275 catches for 3,463 yards and 24 touchdowns in his four-year college career. He can run routes on the outside and is comfortable in the slot. He’s effortlessly smooth off the line; snaps off comeback routes with sharp angles back to the quarterback; has dependable hands; and wastes little movement in his transition to running after the catch. Johnson lacks top-end speed (he ran a disappointing 4.6-second 40-yard dash at the combine) but is a good route runner and is elusive after the catch. He’s strong on contested catches, showing the ability to use subtle push-offs to create space at the catch point. He’s an effort blocker who can position himself well to seal away from the play, but lacks play strength in that area.

Why He Could Rise

Johnson has the upside of a quarterback’s best friend thanks to a combination of size, sure hands, and quality route running.

Why He Could Fall

He’s an average athlete who doesn’t have much speed or burst to separate.

Drew Sample

Tight End

Washington, redshirt senior

  • YDS 252
  • YPR 10.08
  • TDS 3
  • REC 25
  • 20+ 1
Height/Weight6'5'', 255
Age22
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: In-line blocking skills

Reliable “Y” tight end with top-tier run-blocking chops and plenty of athletic upside as a pass catcher.

Shades Of: Jack Doyle
Scouting Report

Sample has a big, rugged frame and smooth, functional athleticism. He isn’t a dynamic route-runner but can threaten the seam and has very good hands, with zero drops in 2018. He’s dominant as a blocker at the point of attack in the run game—he was PFF’s top-graded run blocker at the position in 2018—and uses strong hands to grab and drive defenders away from the play or wall them off from the ball. He keeps a balanced, sturdy base to sustain blocks from snap to whistle, and targets in the open field like a heat-seeking missile, finding his man before breaking down and mirroring.

Why He Could Rise

Sample is a three-down tight end with toughness in the trenches and the physical upside to take a big jump as a receiver.

Why He Could Fall

He was never a big part of Washington’s passing game and lacks explosiveness as a receiver.

Nate Davis

Guard

Charlotte, redshirt senior

  • GMS 8
  • STRTS 7
Height/Weight6'3'', 316
Age22
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Road-grading power

Beefy lineman with the might to uproot defenders in the run game and the light feet to mirror in pass protection.

Shades Of: Shaq Mason
Scouting Report

Davis has a squat, powerful frame with massive legs, a rotund midsection, and a wide upper half. He played at right guard his first three seasons at Charlotte before manning the right tackle spot in 2018. Davis has quick feet, good balance, and a strong punch in pass protection. In the run game, he fires out of his stance with a wrecking-ball mentality and is a nasty finisher who plays through the whistle. He can get caught lunging, and while he starts low to the ground like a sumo wrestler in his pre-snap set, he pops upright in pass protection at times and opens himself up to the bull rush.

Why He Could Rise

Davis is a powerful run blocker with the feet to excel in pass protection. He could play in both zone and gap/power schemes.

Why He Could Fall

He lacks ideal length and is likely to be an interior player only at the next level.

Riley Ridley

Wide Receiver

Georgia, Junior

  • YDS 570
  • YPR 12.95
  • TDS 9
  • REC 44
  • 20+ 7
Height/Weight6'1'', 199
Age22
Main Selling PointMain Selling Point: Razor-sharp routes

Pro-ready pass catcher who lacks top-tier athleticism but combines good size, strong hands, and excellent route-running skills.

Shades Of: Robert Woods
Scouting Report

Ridley has a big, well-proportioned frame with very long arms and huge mitts. His best attribute is his route running; he gets off the line of scrimmage quickly, stresses the cornerback’s cushion, and utilizes sharp cuts to snap routes off and create separation. He’s comfortable working down the sideline and is hard to stop on routes that break back to the quarterback. He’s urgent after the catch, smoothly turning upfield to pick up yards. Ridley is athletically limited and lacked eye-popping production in Georgia’s run-heavy offense, but he did lead the team in catches (43), yards (559), and touchdowns (nine). He projects as a possession receiver at the next level who wins with technique and nuance and not speed or explosiveness.

Why He Could Rise

Ridley’s ability to separate on time underneath could make him an effective possession receiver early in his career.

Why He Could Fall

He offers a lower ceiling than some of his peers in this class because of his lack of high-end athleticism.
